newsitem.title: JAPAN: Crude oil jumps in Asia after U.S. attack on Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Crude oil jumps in Asia after U.S. attack on Iraq.

text.p: Crude oil prices in Asia jumped to fresh four-month highs on Tuesday after the United States launched a cruise missile strike on Iraq in retaliation for Iraqi military attacks on Kurds in the north of the country.
The Pentagon said the attack was made against air defence command and control military targets in and around Baghdad.
The benchmark U.S. light crude oil for October delivery rose to $23.75 per barrel from $23.48 per barrel in the minutes that followed the Pentagon's announcement during Tokyo afternoon trade.

By late afternoon Tokyo, the October contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) had traded up to $24.00. During Asian trading hours, NYMEX crude oil contracts trade on the after-hours ACCESS system.
NYMEX October crude was at its highest level since April 22 and up $1.75 from Friday's close in New York. The New York market was closed on Monday for the U.S. Labor Day holiday.

"The price of crude oil could jump over $30 (per barrel) in the case of WTI," Kazuaki Kondo, a senior economist at the Japanese Institute of Middle Eastern Economies, told Reuters Financial Television following news of the U.S. missile attack against Baghdad.

North Sea Brent October crude, trading on the Singapore International Mercantile Exchange (SIMEX), jumped to $23.50 after the news, up from London's close of $21.99. In late Tokyo afternoon trade, the Brent contract was last traded at $23.00.
Oil traders said the market was being affected both by news of the escalating tensions and the fact that sales of Iraqi crude -- which they had expected to start in September -- were on hold.

United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali had put off plans to implement a $2 billion oil-for-food plan which would allow Iraq to export about 700,000 barrels of oil per day. This would have represented Iraq's return to oil markets after a six-year absence.

"It's a short-term thing. The market will be volatile," one trader said. "The fact that it came after a long weekend did not help. But if the oil sales are put back on track then prices will come off."
But traders said the tensions have come at a sensitive time for the United States.
Stocks of petroleum products such as heating oil and gasoline were at very low levels. In addition, Clinton faces a presidential election in November.
